Investment Program   The  Investment  Program  is  located  in  remote  rural  areas  of 
Description  Zhangye  City  (Zhangye)  of  Gansu  Province  (Gansu),  a  poor 
western province. The Investment Program will partially finance 
the  Heihe  river  cascade  hydropower  development  scheme,  a 
large  infrastructure  project  with  seven  discrete  run-of-river 
medium hydropower plants (HPPs). Construction of the scheme, 
which  started  in  1996,  will  develop  an  aggregated 
645.5 megawatts (MW) of hydropower. Of the seven HPPs in the 
scheme, two are already in operation. Two more HPPs are under 
construction  and  will  be  in  operation  in  2006–2007.  The 
Investment Program involves construction of the next two HPPs in 
the  scheme—(i)  Project  1,  50.5  MW  Erlongshan  HPP;  and 
(ii) Project 2, 60 MW Dagushan HPP. The remaining 112 MW Bao 
Pinghe HPP on the scheme is expected to be constructed through 
public-private  partnership.  A  parallel  rural  grid  improvement 
project to renovate, modernize, and strengthen the 10 kilovolt (kV) 
and 35 kV electricity distribution networks is being financed by the 
Gansu  provincial  government  (GPG)  to  provide  improved  and 
reliable electricity supply to rural consumers in Zhangye. Capacity 
building of the project implementing agencies (PIAs) has been 
carried out as part of the project preparatory technical assistance 
(TA).  
 
The development of the scheme is consistent with GPG’s priority 
and plan to promote hydropower development in Zhangye and 
Gansu  to  meet  the  growing  electricity  demand  in  an 
environmentally sustainable manner. The scheme is an integral 
part  of  the  power  system  planning  and  least-cost  generation 
expansion  plan  in  Gansu  to  provide  additional  generation 
capacity. The scheme is a core infrastructure project included in 
the  Zhangye  city  government’s  (ZCGs)  investment  plan  for 
2006–2010. The scheme is part of the Heihe river basin plan, 
prepared by the Ministry of Water Resources and approved by the 
State Council in 2001.

ii 
Multitranche  Financing  The multitranche financing facility (MFF) amounting to $50 million 
Facility  will help fund the Investment Program and represents about 45% 
of  the  total  financing.  The  individual  and  periodic  financing 
requests  (PFR)  will  be  converted  into  two  loans  in  line  with 
individual  project  readiness,  as  well  as  policy,  safeguards, 
financial management, and fiduciary oversight. The project loans 
will be made from ordinary capital resources (OCR) of the Asian 
Development Bank (ADB). The utilization period of the facility will 
be  7  years.  The  Government  has  entered  into  a  Framework 
Financing Agreement (FFA) with ADB. Pursuant to the FFA, the 
Government has submitted to ADB the first PFR in the amount of 
$22 million. The first PFR is presented to the Board together with 
the FFA. Prior to ADB acceptance of the second PFR, ADB will 
ensure that the Government, the Executing Agency (EA), and the 
PIA comply fully with the terms and conditions of the FFA. An 
ADB team will conduct due diligence to this effect to ensure that 
the  terms  and  conditions  are  satisfactorily  adhered  to.  The 
individual  PFR  should  be  for  a  minimum  loan  amount  of  
$20 million. 
   
Rationale  PRC’s  sustained  economic  growth  and  low  per  capita  energy 
consumption are driving up the demand for electricity, which has 
outpaced economic growth in the last 3 years. The result is power 
shortages in many parts of the PRC. The power shortages have 
affected  the  rural  population  disproportionately.  With  coal-fired 
power plants supplying about 81% of the country’s electricity, the 
electricity sector is a major air polluter. More than 60% of the 
cities do not meet air quality standards. Acid rain falls on one third 
of  the  country.  The  Government  is  committed  to  minimize 
emissions  and  improve  air  quality.  In  2006,  it  enacted  the 
Renewable  Energy  Law,  which  is  expected  to  lead  to  about 
120 gigawatts (GW) of additional clean and renewable energy in 
the country by 2020. Small and medium hydropower development 
is  an  integral  part  of  the  renewable  energy  program  and  is 
expected to provide 80 GW of the additional capacity by 2020.  
 
In Gansu, about 81% of the electricity was produced by coal-fired 
power plants in 2005. Thirteen of Gansu’s 14 cities do not meet 
air  quality  standards;  its  capital,  Lanzhou,  has  the  worst  air 
pollution index of 47 major cities. Some parts of Gansu, such as 
the Hexi corridor, have faced chronic power shortages due to 
limited local generation capacity and large distances from nearby 
power  plants.  Heihe  river,  flowing  in  the  remote  mountainous 
areas  of  Zhangye,  a  predominantly  rural  area  located  in  the 
middle of the Hexi corridor, presents an excellent source of clean 
and  renewable  energy  closer  to  the  power-deficient  area  in 
Gansu. ZCG and GPG are committed to utilize this clean energy 
source to provide benefits to Zhangye and the Hexi corridor in an 
environmentally sustainable manner.

iii 
  ADB  has  an  ongoing  successful  engagement  with  one  of  the 
seven HPPs of the scheme. ADB approved a project loan in 2003 
to support construction of the 102 MW Xiaogushan HPP, which 
was completed in July 2006, 1 year ahead of schedule. Project 
implementation is rated as “highly satisfactory” and has complied 
with all covenants. The PIA, ZCG, and GPG are fully familiar with 
ADB requirements and have the required capacity to implement 
the Investment Program.  
 
ADB is also supporting the development of clean and renewable 
energy in Gansu since 2001. The enactment of the Renewable 
Energy Law, and GPG and ZCG commitment to utilize clean and 
renewable  energy  in  Zhangye  have  created  the  enabling 
conditions  for  accelerated  hydropower  development  on  Heihe 
river.  ADB’s  previous  engagement  in  the  scheme  has 
strengthened  the  rationale  for  the  Investment  Program. 
Considering the discrete components of the scheme, sequential 
construction, and staggered financing needs, the MFF is the most 
appropriate financing tool for the Investment Program.  
 
Impact and Outcome  The Investment Program will provide environmentally clean power 
supply to support economic growth in the rural areas of Gansu. 
This is achieved by providing hydropower generation closer to the 
rural  areas  in  Zhangye  and  the  Hexi  corridor.  This  additional 
generation capacity in conjunction with the ongoing and planned 
Government-financed rural grid rehabilitation and modernization 
program  will  (i)  meet  the  additional  rural  power  demand  to 
overcome shortages; (ii) improve the reliability of power supply to 
rural areas; (iii) facilitate loss reduction; and (iv) advance policy 
reforms in the areas of clean and renewable energy development 
in Zhangye and Gansu.

Implementation  The Investment Program will be implemented over 7 years. GPG 
Arrangements  will be the EA. The projects will be implemented by PIAs, which 
will be project companies created out of the Heihe Hydropower 
Development Company (HHDC). HHDC was formed in 2000 by 
ZCG  to  promote  hydropower  development  in  Zhangye. 
Erlongshan Hydropower Company has already been created as 
the  PIA  for  Project  1.  To  facilitate  national  approvals,  land 
acquisition, licensing arrangements, and to address environmental 
and social safeguard issues related to the Investment Program,  
ZCG  has  formed  a  lead  group  headed  by  a  vice  mayor  of 
Zhangye. A project implementing unit (PIU) in each PIA will be 
responsible for managing, coordinating, and supervising project 
implementation. The PIU is headed by a project manager.

  The Investment Program will be carried out in a poor remote rural 
township. It will require no resettlement, only small nonfarming 
land will be occupied, affecting less than 15 households in all. It 
will provide significant direct benefits to local communities through 
employment generated during construction and operation, access 
to  project  hospitals  and  schools, additional  economic  activities 
that may be supported by more affordable and reliable electricity 
supply.  The  Investment  Program  will  also  provide  significant 
additional tax revenue to the local county government, which may 
be utilized to accelerate economic development.  
 
The projects under the Investment Program are financially viable 
and economically attractive. For Project 1, the financial internal 
rate of return is 5.84%, which is higher than the weighted average 
cost of capital of 4.17%. The economic internal rate of return is 
19.60%, higher than the ADB hurdle rate of 12%. Sensitivity tests 
and risk analysis show that Project 1 will be economically and 
financially viable even under a combination of adverse scenarios. 
The  potential  carbon  revenues  under  the  clean  development 
mechanism (CDM) will further improve the financial and economic 
benefits  from  the  Investment  Program.  The  CDM  benefits  are 
likely  to  provide  additional  revenues  estimated  to  be  about 
10–15% of the project costs. 
   
Risks and Assumptions  The HPPs in the Investment Program have mainly geological and 
hydrological  risks,  which  could  increase  the  cost,  delay  
implementation, or reduce energy output. The projects included in 
the Investment Program are part of an ongoing large infrastructure 
project—Heihe river cascade hydropower development scheme, 
which  is  partially  complete.  The  PIA,  design  institute,  and 
contractors  have  sufficient  knowledge  and  prior  expertise  and 
experience  to  design, construct  and  manage  the  HPPs  in  the 
prevailing  geological  conditions.  The  geological  condition  has 
been  thoroughly  investigated  and  the  civil  work  contracts  will 
include  the  results  of  the  geological  investigations  and  the 
potential  geological  risks.  The  hydrological  data  for  the  last  
60 years were thoroughly investigated by experts to estimate the 
energy output. The associated risk is small. The last HPP is a 
stand-alone project. The delay in implementing the last HPP will 
not in any way affect the viability of the projects included in the 
Investment Program.  
 
The parent company of PIAs, ZCG, and GPG are familiar with 
ADB procedures and requirements from experience in another 
HPP development in the scheme with ADB financing. The PIAs 
and GPG have the required capacity to manage implementation 
of  projects  under  the  Investment  Program—on schedule, within

The electricity tariffs for the Investment Program will be fixed by 
the  Price  Bureau  in  Gansu  Province,  before  commercial

consistent application. The associated commercial risk is small.   
 
In line with the rural development emphasis in the 11th Five-Year

infrastructure. The rural grid improvement project and the uniform

true.

II.  RATIONALE: SECTOR PERFORMANCE, PROBLEMS, AND OPPORTUNITIES 
 
A.  Performance Indicators and Analysis 
 
2.  The PRC has achieved and sustained an impressive economic growth averaging about 9% 
for the past two decades. Compared with its 2000 level, the economy is expected to double by 
2010 and quadruple by 2020. Given the projected growth trajectory and the relatively low1 per 
capita energy consumption of about 0.66 ton of oil equivalent (toe) per annum, the demand for 
energy is expected to increase rapidly. The rapid pace of economic growth has created a strong 
demand for electricity. Per capita electricity consumption has more than quintupled, increasing 
from 340 kilowatt-hours (kWh) in 1983 to 1,840 kWh in 2005.  
 
3.  After the United States, the PRC has the second largest electricity industry in the world. 
Both the installed generation capacity and electricity generation increased at an annual average of 
more than 8% over the past two decades. Since 2002, the electricity demand has increased at an 
average of more than 13%. This resulted in serious power shortages in many areas of the PRC. By 
the end of 2005, the total installed capacity reached 508 gigawatts (GW) and electricity generation 
totaled 2,470 terawatt-hours (TWh), an increase of 13% over 2004. In the past 2 years, 117 GW of 
new generation capacity was added to overcome electricity shortages. To meet the projected 
demand, the installed capacity will have to double from the 2005 level to about 1,000 GW in 2020. 
One of the key challenges to maintain the sustained economic growth is to significantly lower 
energy intensity.2 Energy conservation and improved energy efficiency in the electricity sector are 
the highest priorities of the Government.  
 
4.  In the PRC, electricity is produced overwhelmingly by coal. In 2005, the coal-fired power

B.  Analysis of Key Problems and Opportunities 
 
1.  Key Problems and Constraints 
 
7.  Like many other provinces, Gansu has experienced rapid economic growth and associated 
electricity shortages, which were exacerbated by severe drought in 2003. The Gansu electricity 
network  is  part  of  the  northwest  power  grid,  and  is  a  net  power  importer  from  neighboring 
provinces. Gansu has adequate coal reserves estimated at 9.6 billion t, it also has about 17 GW of 
hydropower potential of which only 4 GW has been exploited. The Gansu electricity network is 
experiencing demand growth of more than 13% in the last 3 years. Consequently, there is a plan 
for rapid generation capacity expansion, emphasizing coal-fired power plants with shorter gestation 
period. Hydropower contribution has sharply declined from 41% in 2000 to 25% in 2005. Coal 
production in the same period has more than doubled from 16 million t to 38 million t. Heavy 
dependence  on  coal  has  exacerbated  air  pollution  in  Gansu.  The  adverse  impacts  of 
environmental pollution have disproportionately affected the poor, who typically rely on raw coal 
and biomass (e.g., wood and animal dung), and suffer accordingly from indoor air pollution. A more 
pronounced  shift  toward  clean  energy  would  reduce  pollution  loads,  energy  intensity,  and 
greenhouse gas. 
 
8.  In  Gansu,  hydropower  potential  is  mainly  located  in  small  to  medium-sized3 HPPs  in 
mountainous  areas.  Development  of  small-  and  medium-sized  HPPs  is  a  local  government 
responsibility. Their development is generally constrained by the local government’s financing 
capacity. Private sector investment in hydropower development is limited to large hydropower 
projects developed by major power utilities. Gansu provincial government (GPG) has drawn an 
extensive plan for local hydropower development to double the present 4 GW capacity to about  
8.5 GW capacity by 2020. In the 11th Five-Year Plan (11FYP), GPG aims to add about 2 GW of 
additional hydropower capacity. In the absence of innovative approaches to project financing and 
private sector participation, the accelerated development of hydropower in Gansu will be severely 
restricted.     
 
9.  Some areas of Gansu, such as the Hexi corridor, have been experiencing chronic power 
shortages due to inadequate local generation capacity and large distances from power plants. 
Zhangye City is located in the middle of the Hexi corridor, about 600 kilometers (km) from the 
provincial capital, Lanzhou (Map 1). Of its 1.27 million population, more than 76% are classified as 
rural. Of its rural population, 293,000 or almost 30% have incomes less than the national rural

2.  Opportunities 
 
10.  The Heihe river, originating between Qilian Mountain and Datong Mountain, is the second 
largest inland river in the PRC and the largest in the Hexi corridor. It traverses northwards through 
Qinghai Province, Gansu, and Inner Mongolia Autonomous Region over a length of more than         
800 km. The river section from Huangzhang Temple to Yingluo Gorge (95 km along the river) in 
Zhangye is an excellent source of hydropower. In this 95 km section of the river, the Heihe river 
cascade hydropower development scheme has identified seven potential HPP sites (Map 2) with a 
total hydropower capacity of 645.5 megawatts (MW). All HPPs in the scheme are medium-sized, 
run-of-river power plants. Details of the scheme are in Appendix 2.  
 
11.  The scheme is an excellent source of emission free and renewable energy located close to 
a power-deficient area, in a designated SO  control zone.5 The scheme is part of the least-cost

population in Zhangye and Hexi corridor. The scheme is also referred to in the Heihe river basin 
plan, prepared by the Ministry of Water Resources and approved by the State Council in 2001. All 
the HPP sites in the scheme are located in remote mountainous rural areas requiring little or no 
resettlement.  
 
12.  To  alleviate  chronic  power  shortages  in  an  environment  friendly  manner  and  to  spur 
economic development of rural areas, the Zhangye city government (ZCG) started the construction 
of the scheme in 1996. The scheme is a core rural infrastructure development initiative at the city 
level. Of the scheme’s seven HPPs, two are already in operation, and two are under construction6 
and  scheduled  for  completion  in  2007.  To  accelerate  the  development  of  the  scheme,  ZCG 
established the Heihe Hydropower Development Company (HHDC) in 2000. Four existing small 
HPPs were transferred to HHDC. ZCG and GPG requested Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
assistance in 2001 for the 102 MW Xiaogushan HPP in the scheme (footnote 6). Construction of 
this HPP was completed in July 2006, 1 year ahead of schedule. ZCG and GPG are committed to 
complete  and  accelerate  scheme  implementation  and  sought  ADB  assistance  through  the 
proposed Investment Program to develop the next two HPPs.

4.  Strategies of the Government and the Asian Development Bank

(ii) encourage cost recovery and better environmental information disclosure. In the water sector,

5.  Lessons 
 
18.  ADB’s  experience  in  the  PRC’s  energy  sector  has  shown  that  projects  are  generally         
well-planned and implemented smoothly. The overall implementation performance of ADB’s energy 
portfolio  is  satisfactory.  Compliance  with  covenants  is  generally  acceptable,  although  greater 
efforts are required to implement policy-related covenants. Rigorous government screening of 
projects has had a positive impact. The project completion and project performance audit reports 
for the energy projects indicate that overall they were implemented smoothly, and assess them as 
generally  successful.  Recently,  some  ongoing  energy  projects  in  the  PRC  have  experienced 
implementation delays relating to long internal approval processes, and procurement issues. Some 
projects have also resulted in substantial loan cancellations to cut costs. The reason is that cost 
estimates were made on international pricing standards with a high level of contingencies, which in 
most cases were not utilized at all. In power projects, generally, the approved tariffs at completion 
have been lower than the estimated tariffs at the project feasibility stage. 
 
19.  The above lessons have been incorporated in the design of the Investment Program. 
Preparation of a detailed feasibility report and its national approval before the submission of 
relevant periodic financing request (PFR), and extensive discussion on policy-related covenants 
were given special emphasis. The cost estimates of Project 1 in the Investment Program were 
rigorously reviewed and adjusted. The price and physical contingencies at a reasonable rate were 
included in the cost estimates. The expected tariff was assumed at a reasonable rate with due 
consideration  to  the  ongoing  tariff  reform  and  prevailing  regulated  generation  tariff  in  2006.

III.  THE PROPOSED INVESTMENT PROGRAM 
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
 
20.  The  Investment  Program  will  provide  environmentally  clean  power  supply  to  support 
economic growth in the rural areas of Gansu. Rural consumers in Zhangye will be supplied with 
reliable, clean, and affordable hydropower. This additional generation capacity in conjunction with 
the ongoing and planned Government-financed rural grid rehabilitation and modernization program

C.  Special Features 
 
  1.  Potential Benefits from Clean Development Mechanism  
 
22.  The Investment Program is anticipated to be eligible for generation of certified emission 
reductions  (CERs)10 under  the  CDM.11 The  CDM  is  a  market-based  financial  instrument  that 
assists developing countries to achieve sustainable development and industrialized countries to 
meet their emission reduction targets. The CDM allows industrialized countries to invest in “clean” 
projects in developing countries to acquire CERs that can be used to comply with the Kyoto 
Protocol.  Emission  reductions  from  the  Investment  Program  will  be  achieved  by  replacing 
equivalent coal-fired power generation. ADB has provided project financing for three CDM projects 
in the PRC, and is currently developing several more projects with CDM potential. The Xiaogushan 
HPP (footnote 6) in the scheme that was financed by ADB loan was the first hydropower project in 
the PRC to successfully contract12 its CERs.  
 
23.  Each project is estimated13 to generate CERs worth about 10–15% of the total project cost. 
HHDC  and  Erlongshan  Hydropower  Company  (EHC)  have  expressed  interest  in  piloting  the 
proposed ADB Carbon Market Initiative (CMI) for Project 1—Erlongshan HPP. Under the CMI, the 
Asia Pacific Carbon Fund can provide up-front purchase of a maximum of 50% of the Erlongshan 
Project’s CER generation. This could represent an estimated up-front payment of $3.5 million, 
which is 7.0% of the total project cost. The CMI can also (i) provide assistance for sale of the 
residual CERs under the Credit Marketing Facility, and (ii) provide grant TA under the Technical 
Support Facility. The CMI is anticipated to be approved by the ADB Board in November 2006 and 
to be operational by early 2007. Project 1 is planned as the pilot for the CMI.

25.  There are 32 ethnic minority nationalities in Zhangye, who account for about 2% of the total

  4.  Private Sector Participation  
 
26.  The continued economic growth and development of physical infrastructure is improving the 
investment  climate  for  private  sector  participation  in  Zhangye  and  Gansu.  ZCG  is  keen  on

seek private investments in the development of HPPs in the scheme. However, private sector 
response has been muted. The main reasons are (i) sensitivity to perceived geological risks, which 
may potentially delay project construction; (ii) limited private capital which gets attracted to large 
power utilities developing bigger power plants at a relatively low cost/kilowatt; and (iii) higher 
transaction costs due to involved multi agency approval and clearance procedures.  
 
27.  Based on experience in other countries and the PRC with projects of similar size, it is easier

47.  During  preparation  of  the  Investment  Program,  Project  1  was  appraised  on  technical,

48.  The Investment Program is based on a least-cost generation expansion plan in Gansu. 
Some indicative financial, economic, social, and environmental analyses of Project 2 were carried 
out based on its prefeasibility studies and are discussed below. The integrated benefits and 
impacts are expected to outweigh the costs. 
 
A.  Economic Analysis 
 
49.  The  demand  forecast  methodology  uses  the  bottom-up  approach  or  sector  analysis 
method. Different end-use demands—primary (agriculture), secondary (industry and construction), 
tertiary (including commercials and services), and residential (urban and rural)—were calculated 
based on current economic activities, policies, and impact of recent major construction projects in 
Gansu. Regression method was used for projecting electricity demand. The regression model used 
electricity  tariff,  GDPs,  population,  industry  structure,  and  energy  efficiency  as  independent 
variables. Historical data for 1990–2004 was taken as input to the regression model. The estimates 
of the regression models (144 TWh) closely matched GPG forecast (129 TWh).  
 
50.  Because of the large gap between demand and supply and a high growth rate of demand in 
Zhangye  and  the  Hexi  corridor,  the  demand-side  responses  were  not  considered  as  full 
alternatives  in  the  analysis.  Only  supply-side  options—new  generating  plants—were  used  as 
available options. The least-cost generation planning for the Gansu provincial power network up to 
2020 was completed under an advisory TA22 in 2002, and the model was updated with actual data 
for 2002–2005. The analysis was also expanded to include the remaining three HPPs in the 
scheme. The least-cost analyses confirmed the robustness of the Investment Program and the 
scheme. The least-cost model optimized the objective function of minimum total system cost—
capital costs, operations costs, and other external cost—to meet the power demand within the 
defined reliability criteria. The least-cost model (i) confirmed the projects under the Investment 
Program to be the least-cost options for additional generation capacity in Gansu, (ii) confirmed the 
Investment Program benefits as incremental electricity supply, and (iii) identified coal-fired power 
plants as the alternatives. Appendix 8 gives the least-cost generation planning and analysis. 
 
51.  The economic internal rate of return (EIRR) for Project 1 was calculated to assess its 
economic viability. Costs considered were capital costs, and operation and maintenance costs. 
Appropriate conversion factors were used to convert financial values into economic values. Values 
are expressed in 2006 local currency. The quantified benefits of Project 1 considered in the 
economic analysis included incremental energy supply through willingness-to-pay. This yielded an 
EIRR of 19.60%. The economic analysis of Project 1 (Appendix 9) does not include environment 
improvement and social benefits. The EIRR calculation is a conservative approach, as it takes into 
account only the main benefits but includes all project-related costs. Sensitivity and risk analyses 
simulating adverse scenarios were carried out, and the EIRR was found to be stable and robust.

E.  Investment Program Risks 
 
69.  An analysis was conducted to ensure sufficient demand for the electricity generated by the 
Investment Program. The risk of insufficient demand is minimal. The electricity generated will 
coincide with the summer peak demand, when electricity shortages are more acute. The regulated 
tariff of CNY0.228/kWh for new HPPs in Gansu reflects the economic supply cost and is expected 
to increase mildly due to fluctuations of the consumer price index. The expected carbon revenues 
from CDM transactions will further improve the PIAs’ financial performance without requiring tariff 
adjustments. Strong economic performance is expected in Gansu, based on the PRC’s emphasis 
on economic development of the western regions. 
 
70.  The projects under the Investment Program are based on proven designs and conventional 
technologies that have been used successfully in the PRC. No significant technical risks are 
anticipated. The hydrological risks that are common to HPPs are minimal as the hydrologic regime 
for the Heihe river is well known, with data for the last 60 years. The accuracy and reliability of the 
recorded historical hydrological data were updated and analyzed by the independent consultant

B.  Lessons  
 
6.  ADB’s overall experience with energy and environment sector projects in the PRC has 
been positive. Projects are generally well-designed and smoothly implemented, although front 
end delays have occurred in some projects. Success is attributed to extensive preparation prior 
to ADB intervention, high sense of local ownership, effective leadership in project management 
offices, and timely policy and enterprise reforms. Delays have also occurred for some projects in 
loan  signing  and  loan  effectiveness,  as  well  as  in  procurement,  construction,  and 
commissioning, but in most cases have not led to unsatisfactory performance. The Government 
has implemented reforms on investment regulations, which simplify approval procedures and 
delegate some approving functions to authorities at the local governments. ADB has been 
working closely with the Government to harmonize the two approval procedures to minimize 
project start-up and implementation delays.   
 
7.  Power utilities, particularly small and medium ones, have been found to be weak in the 
area  of  commercial  and  financial  management.  Often,  there  is  a  need  for  institutional 
strengthening in the areas of organizational structure, delegation of authority, management, 
information and control systems, accounting and financial management, and human resource 
management.  Project  completion  and  project  performance  audit  reports  for  ADB-financed 
projects in the PRC highlight (i) the need to improve financial reporting; (ii) the need for more 
attention to environmental matters; (iii) the advisability of using larger boiler-turbine units; and 
(iv) the necessity for capacity building, not only for project preparation, but also for staff training  
in operational and managerial aspects of power utility operations. Recently, some ongoing 
power projects in the PRC experienced implementation delays in meeting procurement and 
construction deadlines mainly because of the ongoing restructuring of the power sector and

1.  The Gansu power network is part of the north-west power network, located in the west

kilometers and serving about 25 million people. The portion of the Gansu network west of the 
Yellow River is known as the Hexi grid. The Zhangye power network is part of the Hexi network. 
The proposed hydropower plants (HPP) in the Heihe river cascade hydropower development 
scheme—(i)  50.5  megawatts  (MW)  Erlongshan  HPP,  (ii)  60  MW  Dagushan  HPP,  and               
(iii) 112 MW Bao Pinghe HPP—will be connected to the Zhangye, Hexi, and Gansu network

output of these HPPs will be used to meet demand within Gansu province and all (or a major 
part) of its generation will be consumed within the Zhangye and Hexi network.  
 
2.  A least-cost generation planning for the Gansu provincial power network was completed

that technical assistance was updated with the actual data for the year 2003–2005. The analysis 
was also expanded to include the remaining three HPPs in the scheme.  
 
B.  Demand Forecast

future demand is one of the critical variables in selecting the least-cost power plant. A review of 
the actual electricity demand during the 10th Five-Year Plan (2001–2005) in Gansu revealed 
that the electricity demand far exceeded the conservative assumptions of 5.7% per annum 
average growth estimated earlier. The recently observed elasticity of electricity consumption 
with respect to income and the recent economic performance of Gansu suggests that the 
elasticity (percent increase in electricity consumption to per cent increase in gross domestic 
product [GDP]) has been about 1.2 to 1.3.  
 
4.   The demand function also considered the 11 Five-Year Plan (11FYP) priority of the

of 7 %. The time series data for 1995–2004 was used in estimating long-term growth rate. The 
resulting demand projections are in Table A8.1.  
 
5.   Zhangye electricity demand growth (average about 13% since 2001) has also outpaced 
its  economic  growth  (average  about  10%).  The  11FYP  priority  on  rural  development  and
